journal-meta.journal-title: Journal of Intelligent Material Systems and Structures

title-group.article-title: Tracking control of piezoelectric stack actuator using modified Prandtl–Ishlinskii model

article-meta.aff: 1State Key Laboratory of Mechanics and Control of Mechanical Structures, Nanjing University of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Nanjing, China
2Vertical Lift Research Center of Excellence, Department of Aerospace Engineering, Pennsylvania State University, PA, USA

author-notes.corresp: Jinhao Qiu, State Key Laboratory of Mechanics and Control of Mechanical Structures, Nanjing University of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Nanjing, 29 Yudao Street, 210016, China. Email: qiu@nuaa.edu.cn

article-meta.issue-title: Special issue on: ASME 2011 Conference on Smart Materials, Adaptive Structures and Intelligent Systems (SMASIS), Symposium on Modeling, Simulation and Control: Part 1

abstract.p: This article presents the development of Prandtl–Ishlinskii hysteresis model and tracking control of piezoelectric stack actuator with severe hysteresis. Classical Prandtl–Ishlinskii model is a linearly weighted superposition of many backlash operators with different threshold and weight values, which inherits the symmetric property of the backlash operator at about the center point of the loop formed by the operators. To describe the asymmetric hysteresis of piezoelectric stack actuators, two modified operators were developed, one for ascending branches and another for descending branches. Based on this modified model, a feedforward controller was designed to compensate the hysteresis. Since the modified model describes the inverse of hysteresis, the feedforward controller and the hysteresis of piezoelectric stack actuator canceled each other. To attenuate the creep effect and reduce tracking error, a feedback controller was proposed to work with the feedforward controller. Experimental results show that this control scheme that combines feedforward and feedback controllers greatly improves the tracking of the piezoelectric actuator and the error is less than 0.15 µm.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Piezoelectric stack actuators with their high stiffness, fast response, and repeatable nanometer motion have important application for atomic force microscopes (Mokaberi and Requicha, 2008; Schitter et al., 2001), nanopositioner (Sebastian and Salapaka, 2005), and so on. Piezoelectric actuators have the disadvantage of nonlinear effects such as hysteresis and creep, which adversely affects the actuator performance. The response of a piezoelectric actuator to an applied sinusoidal input voltage shows significant hysteresis and creep behavior, which can be 10%–15% in large traversals as shown in Figure 1.

caption.p: Asymmetric hysteresis of piezoelectric stack actuator.

sec.p: Many efforts have been done to counter the nonlinear effects, including electric charge control, closed-loop displacement control, and linear control with feedforward inverse hysteresis model (Ang et al., 2007). Newcomb and Flinn (1982) found that the relationship between the deformation of a piezoelectric actuator and applied charge has significantly less hysteresis than that between deformation and applied voltage. This approach requires specialized equipment to measure and amplify the applied charge, which leads more creep (Schitter et al., 2001) and reduces the responsiveness of the actuator (Ang et al., 2007). In Schitter et al. (2001), the nonlinear behavior of piezoelectric materials, that is, hysteresis and creep was neglected, and a feedback controller was designed to enable the fast image acquisition of an atomic force microscope. The hysteresis effect, which is not incorporated into the actuator system, will act as an unmodeled phase lag. If sufficient phase margin is not provided, it will cause instability in a feedback system (Ge and Jouaneh, 1996). Most of the control methods for piezoelectric actuators use hysteresis model (Ge and Jouaneh, 1996), or inverse model (Ang et al., 2007; Badel et al., 2008; Chen et al., 2010; Lee et al., 2000; Song et al., 2005) in addition to the feedback control. Since the hysteresis of piezoelectric actuator and its inverse canceled each other, the dynamic of piezoelectric actuator system can be considered linear and the linear controller design can be applied.

Various mathematical models have been developed to describe the hysteresis, for example, Prandtl–Ishlinskii model (Ang et al., 2007; Janaideh et al., 2008; Jiang et al., 2010), Preisach model (Ge and Jouaneh, 1996; Li and Tan, 2005; Song et al., 2005), Maxwell resistive capacitor model (Badel et al., 2008; Lee et al., 2000), energy model (Ball et al., 2007; Smith et al., 2003), and Jiles–Atherton model (Hegewald et al., 2007). Among these models, Preisach model and its variations are by far most popular (Song et al., 2005) because these can theoretically describe all rate-independent hysteresis. Preisach model needs a great amount of parameters to achieve more accuracy, which limits it to be incorporated in controller design. Classical Prandtl–Ishlinskii model is a subclass of Preisach model, which is a linearly weighted superposition of many backlash operators with different threshold and weight values. Its advantage is simpler and needs fewer parameters than Preisach model. Hence, Prandtl–Ishlinskii model is more attractive for real-time application. However, the classical Prandtl–Ishlinskii model inherits the symmetry property of the backlash operator at about the center point of the loop formed by the operator. The hysteresis of piezoelectric stack actuator is asymmetric as shown in Figure 1.

In this article, an application of Prandtl–Ishlinskii model in combination with the feedforward and feedback control schemes are designed for piezoelectric stack actuators. In classical Prandtl–Ishlinskii model, the operator can only describe symmetric loops like the parallelogram. To overcome this restriction, two modified operators were developed, one for ascending branches and another for descending branches. The operator for ascending branches equals 0 if the operator output is monotonically decreasing; the operator for descending branches equals 0 if the operator output is monotonically increasing. A simulation was performed to show that the modified model can describe the asymmetric hysteresis. Then a feedforward controller was designed based on the modified model, which can precisely describe the inverse of the hysteresis. In addition, a feedback controller was designed to compensate for actuator creep. Different types of signals are used to test the performance of feedforward and feedback controllers.

sec.title: Classical Prandtl–Ishlinskii hysteresis operator
sec.p: The elementary operator in the Prandtl–Ishlinskii hysteresis model is a linear-play or backlash operator (Ang et al., 2007). It is commonly used in the modeling of backlash between gears with 1 degree of freedom. Analytically, let 0 = t0 < t1 < t2 < … < tN = tE be a partition of time domain [0, tE]. The input x(t) is a continuous function and monotone on each of the subintervals [ti, ti+1]. Then, the backlash operator is defined by (Janaideh et al., 2008)
where u is the input, x is the operator output, r is the input threshold value, and the initial consistency condition of equation (1) is given by
where x0 is the initial state of the operator. For sinusoidal input, the play operator exhibits the parallelogram loop as shown in Figure 2.

caption.p: Parallelogram loops of play operators with thresholds 0.2 and 0.4; δa(t) is the difference between x(t) and u(t) −r; δd(t) is the difference between x(t) and u(t) +r.

sec.title: Modified Prandtl–Ishlinskii hysteresis operator
sec.p: The classical Prandtl–Ishlinskii hysteresis model inherits the symmetric property of the play operator at the center point of the loop formed by the operators. It should be noted that piezoelectric hysteresis loops are not symmetric as shown in Figure 1. This symmetric property weakens the accuracy of the classical Prandtl–Ishlinskii hysteresis model. To overcome this restriction, two modified operators are proposed to describe the asymmetric hysteresis, one for ascending branches and another for descending branches.

For the classical operator r, when its output is monotonically increasing, it equals u(t) −r; when the output is monotonically decreasing, it equals u(t) +r. Then, the difference between output x(t) and u(t) −r can be obtained by
The difference δa(t) equals 0 for x(t) = u(t) −r, and has a maximum 2r at x(t) = u(t) +r.
Similar to δa(t), the difference between output x(t) and u(t) +r is
The difference δd(t) has a maximum 2r at x(t) = u(t) −r, and it equals 0 for x(t) = u(t) +r. Adding equation (2) to equation (3), we have
Specifically, Figure 2 shows the two differences δa(t) and δd(t) for u(t) −r < x(t) < u(t) +r.
The modified operator for ascending branches is given by

where Hr[u, x0](t) is the classical operator, δd(t) is the difference between input x(t) and u(t) +r, which is expressed in equation (3). This operator equals 0 for x(t) = u(t) +r. The modified operator for descending branches can be expressed as
where δa(t) is the difference shown in equation (2). If x(t) = u(t) −r, the output of this operator is 0.

sec.title: Modified Prandtl–Ishlinskii model
sec.p: The classical Prandtl–Ishlinskii hysteresis model describes the hysteresis nonlinearity by a linearly weighted superposition of many play operators with different threshold and weight values (Ang et al., 2007)

with weight vector wh = [wh0…whn] and Hr[u, x0] = [Hr0[u, x00](t) … Hrn[u, x0n](t)]T with the threshold vector r = [r0…rn], where 0 = r0 < … < rn, and the initial state vector x0 = [u00…u0n]T. The threshold parameters r are distributed from 0 to midrange of input, which are usually, but not necessarily, chosen to be equal intervals.
Based on the classical model and equations (5) and (6), the modified Prandtl–Ishlinskii hysteresis model is given by

with weight vector wa = [wa0…wan], wd = [wd0…wdn], and Ar[u, x0] = [Ar0[u, x00](t) … Arn[u, x0n](t)]T, Dr[u, x0] = [Dr0[u, x00](t) … Drn[u, x0n](t)]T with the threshold vector r and the initial state vector x0. The modified model can be expressed as
where Hri[u, x0](t) is the classical operator, δai(t) and δdi(t) is the difference defined by equations (2) and (3).
Specifically, if wai = wdi, for i = 0, 1, 2, …, n, substitute equation (4) into equation (9)

Let whi = 2wairi, i = 0, 1, 2, …n, equation (10) will be the same as equation (7). Hence, the modified Prandtl–Ishlinskii hysteresis model of equation (8) is degraded to classical model in case of wai = wdi, i = 0, 1, 2, …, n.

A simulation was performed for the classical Prandtl–Ishlinskii hysteresis model and modified model. The classical model consists of an operator with the threshold r = 0.2 and weight value wh = 1. The modified model contains the same operator and two weight values, wa = 2, wd = 3. For sinusoidal input, the classical model exhibits symmetric parallelogram loop, but the modified model shows quadrilateral hysteresis in Figure 3. It indicates that the modified Prandtl–Ishlinskii model can describe asymmetric hysteresis.

caption.p: Hysteresis loop of classical model and modified model: (a) classis model, r = 0.2, wh = 1; (b) modified model, r = 0.2, wa = 2, wd = 3.

sec.title: Model identification experiment
sec.p: Figure 4 shows the experimental setup for tracking control. A computer with dSPACE board (DS1103 from dSPACE Ltd) acquires the displacement signal, implements the control algorithm, and generates the control signal. A high-voltage power amplifier (Model 609E-6 from TREK Inc) with a fixed gain of 1000 amplifies the control signal to drive the piezoelectric stack actuator. The displacement of the actuator is measured by a laser sensor (OFV-5000 from Polytec Ltd).

caption.p: ADC: analog-to-digital converter; DAC: digital-to-analog converter.

sec.p: The Prandtl–Ishlinskii model has an advantage of that it is purely phenomenological. There is no direct relationship between model parameters and the physical property of hysteresis. All the parameters can be identified from the measured response. To obtain target data for model identification, the piezoelectric actuator was driven by 0.5 Hz sine wave, and its response was measured by a laser sensor. In order to get an inverse model for real-time control, the target input for identification is the measured displacement, and the target output is the voltage applied on the actuator. To simplify the identification process, the input and output data have been normalized to a range of [0, 1] by the following equations

where V(t) is the voltage applied on the actuator, Vm is the minimum of the voltage, VM is the maximum of the voltage, s(t) is the response displacement measured by the laser sensor, sm is the displacement corresponding to Vm, sM is the response displacement corresponding to VM, and uT(t) and zT(t) are the target input and output for model identification.

In this experiment, the Prandtl–Ishlinskii hysteresis model consists of modified operators with thresholds from 0 to 0.5 of interval 0.05. To avoid the initial loading curve (Ang et al., 2007), the initial state vector is the same as thresholds vector. The turning point as marked in Figure 5 is defined at which one of operators from threshold turn into ascending or descending branch. Then, the weight parameters can be obtained by solving the following equations

caption.p: Normalized hysteresis loop and its turning points.

sec.p: where (xj, yj), j = 1, …, 20 is the coordinate of the turning points shown in Figure 5. The solution to equation (11) is weight parameters as shown in Table 1. Specifically, for operator with threshold 0 and 0.5, wa0 = wd0 and wa10 = wd10 are defined.

caption.p: Weight parameters of modified Prandtl–Ishlinskii model.

sec.p: With the weight parameters shown in Table 1, the simulation result of modified Prandtl–Ishlinskii model is shown in Figure 6. The hysteresis loop estimated by the modified model fits well with the target data.

sec.title: Tracking experiment
sec.p: Inverse control is one of the most popular methods for hysteresis compensation. The concept of inverse control is to design an inverse of the hysteresis nonlinearity (Iyer and Tan, 2009; Nguyen and Ahn, 2009). Since the inverse and the hysteresis of piezoelectric actuator cancel each other out, a pseudo linear system is obtained, and then classic linear controller design can be applied. A tracking control system as shown in Figure 7 was designed with a feedforward controller and a feedback controller. The feedforward controller incorporated the modified Prandtl–Ishlinskii model, which describes the inverse of the hysteresis. The feedback controller was designed to compensate for creep and reduce measurement errors. Then, the voltage applied on the piezoelectric actuator is

where z(t) is the output of modified Prandtl–Ishlinskii model defined by equation (8), CA is the amplification coefficient of the power amplifier, s(t) is the output displacement of the actuator measured by laser sensor, Cb is the coefficient of feedback controller, and

where sd(t) is the desired displacement, Cg represents the gain, which normalizes the desired displacement to a range of [0, 1]. The feedforward and feedback controller can be implemented by MATLAB/Simulink with the experimental setup shown in Figure 4. The dSPACE system compiled the control algorithm and generated the C code that downloaded to the hardware for real-time control purpose.

sec.title: Tracking control with feedforward controller only
sec.p: To find the effectiveness of the control scheme, three different types of tracking signals were used to test the tracking control system. Figures 8 to 10 show the tracking control result for feedforward control, where the solid line represents the desired displacement and the dash line indicates the measured displacement. In Figure 8, only the major ascending branch and different descending branches of hysteresis are followed. Figure 8(a) shows the desired and measured displacement waveforms. Figure 8(b) shows the measured displacement versus desired one. Figure 8(c) shows the tracking error. Figure 8(a) and (c) show that the measured displacement almost exactly equals the desired one. In Figure 9, only the major descending branch and different ascending branches of hysteresis are followed. Figure 9(a) and (c) are similar to the ones presented in the previous figure and the same conclusion can be drawn: the measured displacement follows precisely the desired one. A more complex desired displacement is used in Figure 10. In this case, different ascending and descending branches are followed and minor loops are described. Even in this case, the proposed feedforward controller exhibits good performance. As shown in Table 2, the maximum tracking error with feedforward control is 0.323 µm, indicating that the property of feedforward tracking controller is accurate.

caption.p: Feedforward tracking control for input I: (a) desired and measured displacement, (b) hysteresis loop between desired and measured displacement, and (c) tracking error.
Feedforward tracking control for input II: (a) desired and measured displacement, (b) hysteresis loop between desired and measured displacement, and (c) tracking error.
Feedforward tracking control for input III: (a) Desired and measured displacement, (b) hysteresis loop between desired and measured displacement, and (c) tracking error.
Maximum errors of different control methods.

sec.title: Tracking control using feedforward and feedback controller
sec.p: To improve the performance of the tracking control system, a compound control scheme is designed based on the inverse modified model as feedforward controller and as the feedback controller that can compensate for creep. The same signals are used to test the compound control scheme. The result of this tracking control system is shown in Table 2. The maximum error is 0.137 µm, which indicates that the compound control is more accurate than feedforward control.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: This article presents a modified Prandtl–Ishlinskii hysteresis model and precision tracking control of a piezoelectric stack actuator system using inverse Prandtl–Ishlinskii model and a feedback controller. The good agreement between desired and measured curves shows that modified Prandtl–Ishlinskii model is effective for modeling the asymmetric hysteresis of piezoelectric stack actuator system. The inverse modified model along with the feedback controller is applied to the real-time tracking control of the piezoelectric stack actuator system with both major- and minor-loop hysteresis compensation. Future study will involve developing rate-dependent hysteresis model.
